Our constituents sent us to Congress to do what‘s right, even when it‘s difficult. It’s about changing the way we engage in war and peace. Now it’s up to Congress to debate an AUMF that reflects today and tomorrow’s threats, not yesterday’s forever wars. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/11/opinion/Max-Rose-Elaine-Luria-War-Powers-Vote.html …
I am pleased to vote for this legislation, and I will continue to prioritize the long-term health of Coastal Virginians and protect our drinking water from this carcinogenic contaminant. (2/2)

In Hampton Roads, PFAS present a clear and present threat to our servicemembers and their families. The PFAS Action Act is an important step toward addressing this public health issue with the attention and urgency that it demands.  (1/2) https://luria.house.gov/media/press-releases/congresswoman-luria-champions-legislation-ensure-clean-drinking-water-coastal …

I voted against this resolution because if we must commit our forces to sustained combat operations to protect our nation, Congress has the duty to take on the more urgent task of debating a new AUMF. (3/3)
However, this resolution does not solve the larger problem at hand—which is that we are operating under a nearly two decade-old Authorization for the Use of Military Force (AUMF). (2/3)

Under the Constitution, only Congress has the authority and power to declare war, a responsibility I take seriously. (1/3) https://luria.house.gov/media/press-releases/congresswoman-luria-statement-war-powers-resolution …
